remarks: A bijection between bases which conserves distances and intervals conserves also the property of being a Euclidean geometry. (Contributed by Thierry Arnoux, 23-Mar-2019.)
statement:
f1otrkg.p $e |- P = ( Base ` G ) $.
f1otrkg.d $e |- D = ( dist ` G ) $.
f1otrkg.i $e |- I = ( Itv ` G ) $.
f1otrkg.b $e |- B = ( Base ` H ) $.
f1otrkg.e $e |- E = ( dist ` H ) $.
f1otrkg.j $e |- J = ( Itv ` H ) $.
f1otrkg.f $e |- ( ph -> F : B -1-1-onto-> P ) $.
f1otrkg.1 $e |- ( ( ph /\ ( e e. B /\ f e. B ) ) -> ( e E f ) = ( ( F ` e ) D ( F ` f ) ) ) $.
f1otrkg.2 $e |- ( ( ph /\ ( e e. B /\ f e. B /\ g e. B ) ) -> ( g e. ( e J f ) <-> ( F ` g ) e. ( ( F ` e ) I ( F ` f ) ) ) ) $.
f1otrg.h $e |- ( ph -> H e. V ) $.
f1otrge.g $e |- ( ph -> G e. TarskiGE ) $.
f1otrge $p |- ( ph -> H e. TarskiGE ) $.
$d B e f g $.
$d D e f g $.
$d E e f g $.
$d F e f g $.
$d H f $.
$d I e f g $.
$d J e f g $.
$d P e f g $.
$d e f g ph $.
